content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 20 ยง 154.3 - Change of resident status during year-general rules for filing New York State fiduciary returns for trust

State Regulations

Tax Law, ยง 654(g)
(a) If the status of a trust changes during
its taxable year from resident to nonresident, or from nonresident to resident
(see subdivision [b] of this section), the fiduciary of such trust must file
one New York State fiduciary return as a resident trust for the portion of the
year during which the trust is a resident trust, and one New York State
fiduciary return as a nonresident trust for the portion of the year during
which the trust is a nonresident trust. Furthermore, in determining the New

York taxable income, the New York personal service taxable income and the New

York State minimum taxable income of such trust for the respective periods of
residence and nonresidence, the provisions of sections
154.5
through 154.14 of this Part must be taken into account (if applicable), except
to the extent that the provisions of such sections may be inconsistent with the
provisions of section
618
or section
638
of the Tax Law. (b) (1)

For
purposes of this section, a change of residence of a revocable
inter
vivos
trust or portion thereof will be deemed to have occurred if: (i) a revocable
inter vivos
trust (consisting of property of a person or persons whose property constitutes
such trust or portion thereof) becomes irrevocable; and
(ii)
prior to the time such trust becomes
irrevocable, the domicile of the person or persons whose property constitutes
the trust or portion thereof is different from the domicile of such person or
persons at the time the property was transferred to the trust. (2)

The date on which the change
of residence will be deemed to have occurred is the date on which the revocable
inter vivos
trust becomes irrevocable
inter
vivos, provided that all the conditions prescribed in paragraph (1) of
this subdivision have been satisfied. (3)

If the property of more than one grantor
constitutes the trust and only one of the grantors satisfies the provisions of
paragraph (1) of this subdivision, the respective portions of the property
transferred to the trust by each such grantor must be treated as if separate
trusts had been created by each such grantor. Accordingly, the portion of the
trust which changed its resident status during the taxable year would be
required to file one New York State fiduciary return as a resident trust for
its period of New York State residence and another New York State fiduciary
return as a nonresident trust for its period of nonresidence. However, the
portion of the trust which did not change its resident status must file a New

York State fiduciary return for the entire taxable year as either a resident
trust or a nonresident trust, as the case may be. (4)
A trust which is created as an
irrevocable trust or as a testamentary trust may not change its resident
status. Notes
